citeinfo.origin: Richard M. Wooten assisted by Rebecca S. Latham, Kenneth A. Gillon, Thomas J. Douglas, Stephen J. Fuemmeler, Jennifer B. Bauer, and Anne C. Witt
citeinfo.title: buncosde.BUNCOSDE.LandslideData

pubinfo.publish: North Carolina Geological Survey, Department of Environment and Natural Resources

citeinfo.title: North Carolina Slope Movement and Slope Movement Deposit Database

descript.abstract: The North Carolina slope movement-slope movement deposit (NCSM-SMD) database contains a detailed inventory of slope movements and slope movement deposits. The NCSM-SMD database includes slope movement and deposit type, location, dimensions, dates, geologic (rock and soil), geomorphic, hydrologic, and other site data for individual slope movements and slope movement deposits where known. Initial NCSM-SMD data collection by the North Carolina Geological Survey (NCGS) began in 1990, but the impetus to assemble these data arose from a collaborative effort, beginning in 2004, between the North Carolina Division of Emergency Management (NCDEM) and the NCGS, to establish a statewide inventory of geological hazards. Further impetus to develop the NCSM-SMD database resulted from at least 140 slope movements triggered by the inland tracking of hurricanes during September 2004. These slope movements resulted in a total of five deaths and at least 30 destroyed or heavily damaged homes in North Carolina. As a result, the North Carolina General Assembly tasked the NCGS with developing landslide (slope movement) hazard maps for the 19 counties listed in the Hurricane Recovery Act of 2005. This file contains the NCSM-SMD entries within Buncombe County and serves as a portion of the deliverables for completion of landslide hazard mapping in that county. The project data is stored in a MS Access database in the NCGS's Swannanoa office.
descript.purpose: These data provide an inventory of slope movements and slope movement deposits in Buncombe County North Carolina as of 1 August 2006 as part of the Landslide Hazard Mapping program commissioned by the NC General Assembly in the Hurricane Recovery Act of 2005.
descript.supplinf:
This data set refers to professional publications in the attribute fields. These publications are: ASTM 2487-85, 1985, Standard Test Method for Classification of Soils for Engineering Purposes, Annual Book of ASTM Standards, Volume 04.08.
ASTM 2488-84, 1984, Standard Practice for Description and Identification of Soils (Visual-Manual Procedure), Annual Book of ASTM Standards, Volume 04.08.
Bates, R.L., and Jackson, J.A., eds., 1987, Glossary of geology: 3rd ed., American Geological Institute, 788 p.
Bureau of Reclamation, Engineering Geology Field Manual.
Clark, G.M., 1987, Debris slide and debris flow historical events in the Appalachians south of the glacial border, in Costa, J.E., Wieczorek, G.F., eds., Debris flows/avalanches: process, recognition, and mitigation: Geological Society of America reviews in engineering geology v. VII, p. 125-138.
Cruden, D.M. and Varnes, D.J., 1996, Landslide types and processes, in Landslides: Investigation and Mitigation, Turner, A.K. and Schuster, R.L., eds. Transportation Research Board Special Report No. 247, National Research Council, National Academy Press, Washington, D.C., p. 36-75.
Varnes, D.J., 1978, Slope movement types and processes, in Landslide Analysis and Control, edited by R.L. Schuster and R.J. Krizak, Transportation Research Board Special Report No. 176, National Academy of Sciences, Washington, D.C., p. 11-33.
Williamson, D.A., 1984, Unified rock classification system, Bulletin of the Association of Engineering Geologists, vol. XXI, no. 3, August, 1984, pp 345-354.
List of abbreviations:
ASU: Appalachian State University DEM: Digital elevation model DOQQ: Digital ortho quarter quandrangle EBCI: Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians EM: Emergency Management FHWA: Federal Highway Administration HRD: Highlands Ranger District LiDAR: Light Detecting and Ranging LQS: North Carolina Department of Environment and Natural Resources Land Quality Section MVSD: Maggie Valley Sanitation District NCCGIA: North Carolina Center for Geographic Information Analysis NCDEM: North Carolina Division of Emergency Management NCDOT: North Carolina Department of Transportation NCGS: North Carolina Geological Survey NPS: National Park Service NRCS: Natural Resources Conservation Service TIMS: NCDOT Traveler Information Management System USFS: United States Forest Service USGS: United States Geological Survey
Glossary of commonly used terms:
apex: The uppermost and usually narrowest part of a debris fan deposit nearest the source area of the fan.
azimuth: Bearing of a linear geologic structure measured in a vertical plane that passes through the structure.
bearing: The horizontal direction of a line on the Earth's surface with reference to the cardinal points of the compass.
bedding: The arrangement of sedimentary rock into layers of various thicknesses.
blowout: A rare to common type of slope failure in which material appears to burst forth from the ground and then proceed downslope as overland flow. These are possibly caused by excessive pore water pressure. (from Clark, 1987)
brittle fault: A displacement or offset within a rock mass characterized by brittle (non plastic) behavior evidenced by angular broken rock fragments or minerals.
clay: A fine-grained soil that can be made to exhibit plasticity within a range of water contents and that exhibits considerable strength when air dry having a diameter less than 0.003 inches as defined by ASTM 2487-85.
compositional layering: An outcrop- or hand sample-scale structure in metamorphic rocks produced by subparallel layers of various origins that cannot be confidently identified as bedding.
creep: The slow, more or less continuous downslope movement of mineral, rock, and soil particles by gravity.
cut slope: A slope exposed by excavating earth materials.
debris flow: A type of slope movement in which the displaced mass is composed of debris and the water content in the displaced mass is sufficient for the material to liquefy and resemble a viscous fluid.
debris slide: A slope movement initiated by slippage along a well-defined failure surface that is usually planar or curvi-planar in which the displaced mass is composed of debris. Slides are divided into two classes, rotational and translational. Slides usually consist of displaced and deformed blocks of material.
debris slide-flow: A slope movement with characteristics of a debris slide and a debris flow. A slope movement may begin as a debris slide, and then mobilize into a debris flow if sufficient water is available.
deposit: Earth material of any type that has accumulated by some natural process or agent.
dip: The angle (0-90 degrees) that a sloping surface makes with a horizontal plane.
ductile fault: A displacement or offset within a rock mass characterized by plastic (non-brittle) behaviousr of rock and mineral fragments evidenced by elongated, non-angular rock fragments and minerals.
earth flow: A type of slope movement in which the displaced mass is composed of earth and the water content in the displaced mass is sufficient for the material to liquefy and resemble a viscous fluid.
earth slide: A slope movement initiated by slippage along a well-defined failure surface that is usually planar or curvi-planar in which the displaced mass is composed of debris.
embankment: Man-placed deposits of natural earth materials, example rock, soil, or gravel, used to extend a side slope or a land surface, example for a roadway or building site, build up low-lying land, hold back water, example a dam, or fill in an enclosed space, example mine workings. Synonymous with man-made fill, but distinguished from naturally occurring, sedimentary fill.
felsic: An igneous or metamorphic rock having abundant light colored minerals (chiefly feldspar and quartz) in its composition; also, said of those minerals.
foliation: The planar arrangement of textural or structural features in a metamorphic rock that results from flattening or alignment of the constituent mineral grains.
foot slope: The lower gentle slope of a hillside below a steep rock face or escarpment including lower slopes of diminishing steepness; used here to generally designate the lower third of a hillslope.
formation: A body of rock identified by its unique lithologic characteristics and stratigraphic position.
fracture: A general term for any break in a rock, whether or not it causes displacement, due to mechanical failure by stress. (see joint)
gravel: An unconsolidated, natural accumulation of rock fragments resulting from erosion and consisting predominantly of particles larger than sand but smaller than cobbles greater than 0.19 inches and smaller than 3 inches as defined by ASTM 2487-85.
ground water: Water below the surface of the Earth. Also spelled: groundwater, ground-water.
head: The upper parts of the slope movement material in contact between the displaced material and the main scarp.
igneous rock: A rock that solidified from molten or partly molten magma.
intrusive: Igneous rocks crystallized from magma beneath the surface of the Earth.
joint: A fracture or parting in a rock, without displacement. (see fracture)
landslide: An informal term for a wide variety of mass movement landforms and processes involving the downslope transport, under gravitational influence, of soil and rock material en masse. The term "slope movement" is used here instead to include movement by flowing, falling and sliding.
LiDAR: Topographic data obtained by Light Detecting and Ranging method and provided by N.C. Floodplain Mapping Program at 6 m pixel resolution.
lithology: The description of rocks, especially in hand specimen and in outcrop, on the basis of such characteristics as color, mineral composition, and grain size (adj lithologic).
mafic: An igneous or metamorphic rock composed chiefly of one or more ferromagnesian, dark-colored minerals; also, said of those minerals.
metaigneous rock: a metamorphosed igneous rock.
metamorphic rock: A rock derived from metamorphism of a pre-existing rock.
metamorphism: Solid-state recrystallization of a pre-existing rock by heat and pressure.
metasedimentary rock: A metamorphosed sedimentary rock.
midslope: the middle third of a slope proportioned approximately from ridge top to toe slope.
mineral: A naturally occurring, inorganic substance having an orderly internal crystalline structure, characteristic chemical composition, and physical properties.
pebble: A general term for a small, rounded, water-worn stone; specifically, a rock fragment larger than a granule and smaller than a cobble, having a diameter in the range of 4 mm to 64 mm.
plunge: The inclination from horizontal of a linear structure, measured in the vertical plane.
pore water: Subsurface water in the voids of rock, sediment, or soil.
quadrangle: A rectangular area bounded by parallels of latitude and meridians of longitude. In this database, "quadrangle" means a USGS 7.5-minute topographic quadrangle map, 1:24,000 scale.
regolith: A general term for the layer or mantle of fragmental and unconsolidated rock material that nearly everywhere forms the surface of land and overlies or covers bedrock. It includes alluvium, colluvium, residuum, debris, earth, and soil.
rock fall: A type of slope movement in which a single mass of rock of any size is detached from a steep slope or cliff along a surface on which little or no shear displacement occurs. The detached material descends mostly through the air by free fall, bounding, or rolling.
rock slide: A slope movement initiated by slippage along a well-defined failure surface that is usually planar or curvi-planar in which the displaced mass is composed of rock that was intact and in its natural place before the initiation of movement.
rotational movement: A term used to describe the type of movement in a slide in which the displaced material has moved along a curved, concave upward, failure surface.
sand: A rock or mineral fragment or a detrital particle of any composition smaller than a granule and larger than a coarse silt grain, having a diameter between 0.003 inches and 0.19 inches as defined by ASTM 2487-85.
saprolite: A soft, earthlike, completely decomposed, or weathered, in-place rock material typically formed in humid environments. Saprolite is characterized by the preservation of structures that were present in the unweathered rock.
scar: A cliff, precipice, or other steep slope, that corresponds to the zone of depletion, or the area from which a slope movement originated.
scarp: A cliff like face or slope that breaks the general continuity of the land surface around or in a slope movement, and coincides with a rupture of the ground surface with differential displacement. The main scarp is above the head of the slope movement, and usually forms the upper periphery of the displaced mass; a minor scarp is a rupture of the ground surface with differential displacement in the body of the displaced mass.
sediment: Loose, unconsolidated, fragmental material that originates from weathering of rocks and is transported or deposited by air, water, or ice.
sedimentary rock: A rock resulting from the consolidation of loose sediment that has accumulated in layers; also a rock formed by precipitation from solution, or an organic rock consisting of the remains or secretions of plants and animals.
shear strength: The internal resistance of a body to shear stress.
silt: A soil less than 0.003 inches in diameter that is nonplastic or very slightly plastic and that exhibits little or no strength when air dry as defined by ASTM 2487-85.
slickenlines: Grooves and ridges that appear on polished fault surfaces; commonly associated with brittle faults.
slope movement: The gradual or rapid downslope movement by falling, flowing, or sliding or combinations of these of regolith or rock by gravity. Used here in place of the term 'landslide.'
slide: A slope movement initiated by slippage along a well-defined failure surface that is usually planar or curvi-planar. Slides are divided into two classes, rotational and translational. Slides usually consist of displaced and deformed blocks of material.
strike: The direction or trend of a planar surface in bedrock, example a bedding, foliation, or fault plane, as it intersects the horizontal.
structure: A feature in the rock that results from rock deformation.
sulfidic: A modifier for a rock that contains a visible component of sulfide minerals (e.g., pyrite, pyrhotite, cahlcopyrite).
surficial deposit: An unconsolidated and residual, alluvial, or glacial deposits lying on bedrock or occurring on the Earth's surface. (see regolith)
tension crack: A crack or rupture in the ground surface caused by extension or tensile stress but not showing differential vertical displacement. With continued vertical displacement, a tension crack can become a scarp.
toe: The lowest part of a slope, slope movement or slope movement deposit.
topographic map: A map showing the topographic features of the land surface.
track: The path of a channelized debris flow between the scar or initiation zone upslope, and the toe or depositional area downslope. The track usually coincides with a pre-existing stream channel or drainage way.
translational movement: A term used to describe the type of movement in a slide in which the displaced material has moved along a generally planar failure surface.
upper slope: The upper third of a slope proportioned from the ridge top to the toe slope but excluding the ridge top.
weathered-rock slide: A term used to describe a rockslide where the displaced rock is partly- to completely-decomposed (in accordance with Williamson (1984)) from physical and chemical weathering processes.
weathering: The physical disintegration and chemical decomposition of rock at the Earth's surface.

idinfo.useconst: The North Carolina Department of Environment and Natural Resources (NCDENR), North Carolina Geological Survey (NCGS) is charged by the State of North Carolina to develop landslide hazard assessment maps for the Blue Ridge region of western North Carolina. NCGS is committed to offering its users accurate, useful, and current information. All electronic and/or hardcopy products (maps, data, and text, etc.) produced by this landslide hazard assessment program are considered public information (unless otherwise noted) and may be distributed or copied. These products, however, are intended to serve for general planning purposes only, and are provided on an "as is" basis. USE OF THESE MATERIALS CONSTITUTES ACCEPTANCE OF THIS DISCLAIMER OF LIABILITY. Therefore, the client must be aware of data conditions and bear responsibility for the appropriate use of the information with respect to possible errors, original map scale, collection methodology, currency of data, and other conditions specific to certain data. The user must be cautious when using these data, as none of the data represented here are perfect. Also, as in many complex scientific endeavors, error can be expected. In no event shall NCDENR, NCGS, or its employees be liable for any direct, indirect, incidental, special, exemplary, or consequential damages (including, but not limited to, procurement or substitute goods or services; loss of use, data, or profits; or business interruption) however caused and on any theory of liability, whether in contract, strict liability, or tort (including negligence or otherwise) arising in any way out of the use of these data, even if advised of the possibility of such damage.
idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 3; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.1.3000

attracc.attraccr: North Carolina Geologic Survery collects locations and maintains a Microsoft Access database of slope movement and slope movement deposits. The database includes rock and soil classification, location information, geomorphic site description and surface and ground water conditions. The data is converted from Access to an ESRI shapefile. All attributes are reviewed by the staff geologists.

dataqual.logic: Using Latitude/Longitude values for each record a XY event theme was created for each record as a point in the Slope Movement database. The event theme was then converted into a point shapefile in ESRI ArcGIS.
dataqual.complete: These data represent discrete, point locations of slope movements and slope movement deposits documented by the NCGS.

procstep.procdesc: A data source provided information to the NCGS concerning a slope movement or a slope movement deposit. Where site visits were made, NCGS staff visited the location of the landslide to collect detailed information on location, geomorphology, soil and rock properties, and hydrologic conditions at the initiation zones of slope movements or at the apexes of slope movement deposits. All structural measurements were made using Brunton compass unless otherwise noted; all measurements follow right hand rule. This information was collected using the best professional judgment of the NCGS staff by hand either in a field notebook or on a landslide field sheet. If a site visit was not made, all pertinent information that could be reasonably obtained through a literary source or digitally using Arc GIS was collected. Data was then entered into an Access database.

cntperp.cntorg: North Carolina Geological Survey, Department of Environment and Natural Resources

altsys.altenc: Explicit elevation coordinate included with horizontal coordinates

enttyp.enttypd: Locations of slope movements and slope movement deposits in Buncombe County, North Carolina

attr.attrdef: The initial or initials of NCGS investigators
Internal feature number.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Feature geometry.
Internal ascension number.
The type of entry in the database

edom.edomvd: A known specific slope movement where a movement mechanism and/or date is known, or can be readily inferred
A slope movement deposit that cannot be associated with a specific slope movement event and is typically prehistoric in age

attr.attrdef: Name of the project for which the data was collected, example Blue Ridge Parkway or Landslide Hazard Mapping
the USGS 7.5-minute topographic quadrangle name

edom.edomvd: 24k quadrangle name

24k quadrangle name

24k quadrangle name
24k quadrangle name

attr.attrdef: The informal geographic name of slope movement designated by NCGS, example Charley Branch #4

The classification of slope movement material as one of the following: earth, debris, rock, weathered rock, composite - specify, other - specify; this in combination with the slope movement mechanism provides the type of slope movement; classified according to Varnes (1978) and Cruden and Varnes (1996.

edom.edomvd: Regolith in which about 80% or more of the particles are smaller than 2 mm. Earth is a general term used to classify the finer-grained type of material in the source area of a slope movement, examples earth flow or earth slide.

Regolith that contains a significant proportion of coarse material in which 20% to 80% of the particles are greater than sand sized in the range of 0.08 in or 2 mm. Debris is a general term used to classify the coarser-grained material in the source area of a slope movement, example debris flow or debris slide
An aggregate of one or more minerals, undifferentiated mineral matter, or solid organic material.
Rock is partly to completely decomposed from physical and chemical processes.
a type of slope movement in which different types of movement occur in different areas and in different material of the displaced mass, sometimes simultaneously.
Not one of the other broad catagories

attr.attrdef: the classification of the slope movement mechanism
attr.attrdefs: to Varnes (1978) and Cruden and Varnes (1996)

edom.edomvd: a type of slope movement in which different types of movement occur in different areas of the displaced mass, sometimes simultaneously

A type of slope movement in which material is detached from a steep slope or cliff along a surface on which little or no shear displacement occurs. The detached material descends mostly through the air by free fall, bounding, or rolling.
A type of slope movement in which the water content in the displaced mass is sufficient for the material to liquefy and resemble a viscous fluid
Anything that does not fall under the broad catagories.
Downslope movement of a soil or rock mass occurring dominantly on surfaces of rupture or on relatively thin zones of intense shear strain. Used when mode of sliding is unknown.
A slide that moves along a surface of rupture that is curved and concave.
A slide in which the mass displaces along a planner or undulating surface of rupture.
A slope movement in which a relatively intact body of material develops lateral fractures and slides over a softer, underlying material. These often result from liquefaction.
A slope movement in which material moves forward out of the slope about a point or axis below the center of gravity of the displaced mass.

attr.attrdef: The classification of slope movement deposit.

edom.edomvd: A deposit of debris sized material that is known or reasonably inferred to be emplaced by mass wasting processes but lacks distinctive lobe, fan, or coalescing fan shape of a debris fan.
edom.edomvds: NCGS based on Cruden, D.M. and Varnes, D.J., 1996

edom.edomvd: A deposit of debris-sized material that is known or reasonably inferred to be emplaced by mass wasting processes and has a distinctive lobe, fan, or coalescing fan shape. Debris fan can include colluvial and alluvial components.
edom.edomvds: NCGS based on Cruden, D.M. and Varnes, D.J., 1996

edom.edomvd: A deposit of earth sized material that is known or reasonably inferred to be emplaced by mass wasting processes but lacks distinctive lobe, fan, or coalescing fan shape.
edom.edomvds: NCGS based on Cruden, D.M. and Varnes, D.J., 1996

edom.edomvd: A deposit of earth sized material that is known or reasonably inferred to be emplaced by mass wasting processes and has a distinctive lobe, fan, or coalescing fan shape.
edom.edomvds: NCGS based on Cruden, D.M. and Varnes, D.J., 1996

edom.edomvd: A deposit of unknown grain size that has distinctive lobe, fan, or coalescing fan shape.
edom.edomvds: NCGS based on Cruden, D.M. and Varnes, D.J., 1996

edom.edomvd: Slope movement deposits that mantle hillslopes without a distinctive fan shape or fabric indicating flow (e.g., imbrication). This deposit is primarily emplaced by creep rather than by more rapid forms of mass wasting processes such as flow or sliding. It is a general term applied to a deposit with an emplacement mechanism that is not known or reasonably inferred.
edom.edomvds: NCGS based on Cruden, D.M. and Varnes, D.J., 1996

edom.edomvd: An accumulation of boulders or angular blocks of rock, with little or no fine sediment in the upper part over bedrock or other hillslope deposit without a cliff or a ledge above as an apparent source. Block fields usually occur on high mountain slopes where they are most extensive along slopes parallel to contour
edom.edomvds: NCGS based on Cruden, D.M. and Varnes, D.J., 1996

edom.edomvd: A linear accumulation of boulders or angular blocks of rock, with little or no fine sediment in the upper part over bedrock or other hillslope deposit. Block streams usually occur at heads of ravines, as narrow bodies more extensive downslope than along slope.
edom.edomvds: NCGS based on Cruden, D.M. and Varnes, D.J., 1996

edom.edomvd: A rock fragments of any size or shape, usually coarse and angular, derived from and lying at the base of a cliff or very steep rocky slope.
edom.edomvds: NCGS based on Cruden, D.M. and Varnes, D.J., 1996

edom.edomvd: Combination of the defined values or anything that does not fall under the defined categories.

attr.attrdef: date of the slope movement in month, day, year data format where known. If the complete date is not known, month and year of failure or just year of failure has been entered.
date the data was collected in month, day, year data format
The county name where the slope movement or slope movement deposit is located

edom.edomvd: State of North Carolina

attr.attrdef: The latitude of the initiation zone of a slope movement in decimal degrees to 5 decimal places if possible
The longitude of the initiation zone of a slope movement in decimal degrees to 5 decimal places if possible
The latitude of the apex of a slope movement deposit in decimal degrees to 5 decimal places if possible.
The longitude of the apex of a sloe movement deposit in decimal degrees to 5 decimal places if possible.
Road name and/or road number affected by or in close proximity to the slope movement or slope movement deposit
Azimuth orientation of the road
The downslope aspect at the initiation zone of a slope movement or at the apex of a slope movement deposit.
The source of data, example NCGS, USFS, EM-Swain County

attrdomv.udom: Entities that informed NCGS of the slope movement or slope movement deposit

attr.attrdef: Confidence in accuracy of latitude-longitude location

edom.edomvd: USGS 7.5-minute topographic quadrangle with a positional accuracy accurate within a 400-foot radius in the worst case
field verified using GPS with an accuracy within a 40-foot radius
aerial photograph location accuracy varies, but is accurate within a 200-foot radius in the worst case
LiDAR is accurate within a 50-foot radius
not field verified by NCGS, but field verified by another source with accuracy unknown
Unknown, location not field verified by NCGS or other known entities.

attr.attrdef: The elevation above mean sea level in feet determined from either USGS 7.5-minute topographic quadrangle or from the LiDAR DEM of head of slope movement
The elevation above mean sea level in feet determined from either USGS 7.5-minute topographic quadrangle or from the LiDAR DEM of apex of slope movement deposit
the elevation above mean sea level in feet determined from either the USGS 7.5-minute topographic quadrangle or from the LiDAR DEM of the toe of the slope movement or slope movement deposit.

Configuration of slope on which movement or deposit occurred; options include: road cut, road embankment, road unspecified, unmodified, cut slope - not road related, embankment - not road related, river erosion, other-specify

edom.edomvd: A slope exposed by excavating earth material related to a roadway
Man-placed deposits of natural earth materials used to extend a side slope or a land surface for a roadway
A roadway without a specified configuration
Slope has been unmodified by man.
A slope exposed by excavating earth materials not related to a roadway
Man-placed deposits of natural earth materials used to extend a side slope or a land surface for something other than a roadway
Configuration formed through river erosional forces.
Any other slope configuration that does not fall into the defined catagories

attr.attrdef: Relative geomorphic position of the initiation zone of a slope movement or the apex of a slope movement deposit. This is determined visually from the USGS 7.5-minute topographic quadrangle or the LiDAR DEM by looking at the relative placement of the data point with respect to the top of the slope and the base of the slope.

edom.edomvd: The surface or strip of relatively smooth land adjacent to a river channel constructed by the present river in its existing regimen and covered with water when the river overflows its banks.
Middle third of the slope that lies topographically below the upper slope and above the toe slope
Combination of the other values
Thin, narrow crest of the hillside
Lower third of the slope that lies topographically below the mid slope and above the flood plain
Upper third of the slope that lies topographically below the ridge tope and above the mid slope

attr.attrdef: Relative geomorphic shape of the ground surface at the initiation zone of a slope movement.

edom.edomvd: a slope that curves inward
a slope that curves outward
a slope that is concave parallel and perpendicular to the slope
slope shape different from the available options
a slope that is flat and does not curve

attr.attrdef: Relative geomorphic structure at the initiation zone of a slope movement.

edom.edomvd: dip direction of the slope is coincident (within 15 degrees) to the dip direction of primary bedding or foliation of the bedrock
dip direction of the slope is at an oblique angle to the dip direction of primary bedding or foliation of the bedrock
geomorphic structure differs from the available options
dip direction of the slope is at an approximate 180-degree angle (within + 15 degrees) to the dip direction of primary bedding or foliation of the bedrock

attr.attrdef: the estimated length in feet of the displaced mass of a slope movement or a slope movement deposit. The estimate is made either visually while at the site or is scaled from an aerial photograph, USGS 7.5-minute topographic quadrangle, or LiDAR DEM.

the estimated width in feet of the displaced mass of a slope movement measured at the initiation zone. The estimate is made either visually while at the site or is scaled from an aerial photograph, USGS 7.5-minute topographic quadrangle, or LiDAR DEM
the estimated thickness in feet of the displaced mass. The estimate is usually made visually while at the site

the length in feet of a debris flow track from the head to the toe. The estimate is made either visually while at the site or is scaled from an aerial photograph, USGS 7.5-minute topographic quadrangle, or LiDAR DEM
the text narrative of any damage or impacts of slope movement
text narrative of movement history including dates, rates of movement if continued beyond initial date of movement, and information on any stabilization actions if known.
geologic map unit for the initiation point or apex as determined from the 1985 NCGS State Geologic Map
geologic map unit for the initiation point of apex as determined from any other geologic map of the area.
General type of vegetation in the initiation zone based either on visual observation or from aerial photograph. Attribute_Definition_Source: NCGS

edom.edomvd: General type of vegetation in the initiation zone based either on visual observation or from aerial photograph.
General type of vegetation in the initiation zone based either on visual observation or from aerial photograph.
General type of vegetation in the initiation zone based either on visual observation or from aerial photograph.
General type of vegetation in the initiation zone based either on visual observation or from aerial photograph.
General type of vegetation in the initiation zone based either on visual observation or from aerial photograph.
General type of vegetation in the initiation zone based either on visual observation or from aerial photograph.
General type of vegetation in the initiation zone based either on visual observation or from aerial photograph.
General type of vegetation in the initiation zone based either on visual observation or from aerial photograph.

attr.attrdef: Slope in degrees of the original ground surface at the initiation zone or; abbreviations in parentheses indicate the location or type of slope where the measurement was taken (i.e., "e" for embankment, "c" for cut, "o" for original, undisturbed ground, "rflank" for right flank)
Field classification of primary rock type at the initiation zone.
Field classification of secondary rock type at the initiation zone.

edom.edomvd: Less than two percent sulfides visible
Between two and five percent sulfides visible

No sulfides visible

edom.edomvd: No sulfides visible

edom.edomvd: Clay, silt, sand, gravel or similar unconsolidated detrital earthen material deposited during relatively recent geologic time by a stream or other body of running water. Alluvium usually contains rounded particles and usually collects in the channels and floodplains of creeks, streams, rivers, and lakes
edom.edomvds: NCGS based on Bates and Jackson (1987)

edom.edomvd: Any loose, heterogeneous, and unconsolidated mass of soil and rock particles deposited by rainwash, sheetwash, or slow, continuous downslope creep. Colluvium usually contains angular to subrounded rock particles and usually collects at the base or other low gradient portions of slopes or hillsides.
edom.edomvds: NCGS based on Bates and Jackson (1987)

edom.edomvd: An unconsolidated or partly weathered, parent material soil, that developed in place by the physical and chemical weathering from the consolidated rock on which it lies
Man-placed deposits of natural earth materials.
edom.edomvds: NCGS based on Bates and Jackson (1987)

attr.attrdef: Relative overall textural classification of soil unit 2/secondary soil; options include the following

edom.edomvd: a soil in which the majority is composed of coarse-grained rock masses that are in direct contact with one another.

soil is composed of coarse-grained rock fragments suspended in fine-grained soil, and the rock fragments are not typically in direct contact with one another. Enumerated_Domain_Value_Definition_Source: NCGS
Some other make-up other then Clast or Matrix support

attr.attrdef: ASTM classification of soil unit 2/secondary soil

edom.edomvd: boulder - A detached rock mass larger than a cobble, having a diameter greater than 12 inches
cobble - A rock fragment larger than a pebble and smaller than a boulder, having a diameter in the range of 3 inches to 12 inches

gravel - An unconsolidated, natural accumulation of rock fragments resulting from erosion and consisting predominantly of particles larger than sand but smaller than cobbles greater than 0.19 inches and smaller than 3 inches

attr.attrdef: description of the groundwater conditions at the initiation zone of a slope movement or the apex of a slope movement deposit if known

edom.edomvd: groundwater is discharging in the bedrock along one or more discontinuities
no evidence of groundwater was observed at the site
groundwater conditions differ from the options listed in the pull down menu
groundwater is discharging along the contact between the bedrock and the overlying soil
Groundwater is discharging within the soil/sediment

attr.attrdef: Description of the surface water conditions at the initiation zone of a slope movement or the apex of a slope movement deposit if known

edom.edomvd: the natural ground conditions have been modified so that surface water is directed onto the slope movement
the natural ground conditions direct surface water onto the slope movement
no surface water was observed at the site
surface water conditions differ from the other options listed in the pull down menu
drainage from a road flows onto the slope movement
water is ponded on the slope movement

attr.attrdef: indication of whether or not a geologic cross-section has been constructed for that location

edom.edomvd: yes - geologic cross section has been constructed
no - geologic cross section has not been constructed
other then yes or no

attr.attrdef: Indication of whether or not a plan map has been constructed for that location;

edom.edomvd: Yes - plan map constructed
No - no plan map constructed
Something other then a plan map

attr.attrdef: Indication of whether or not photos have been taken of that location

edom.edomvd: Photos have been taken
Photos have not been taken
Some other definition

attr.attrdef: Indication of whether or not precipitation data is available for that location at the time of the slope failure

edom.edomvd: Precipitation data is available
No precipitation data available
other information regarding precipitation data

attr.attrdef: Indication of whether or not a polygon has been drawn in a shape file representing the extent of the slope movement or slope movement deposit.
indication of type of testing performed on material in a slope movement or slope movement deposit. If field is left blank, no testing was performed at that location.

edom.edomvd: Rock tests were performed on samples from this location
Soil tests were performed on samples from this location
Both rock and soil tests were performed on samples from this location

attr.attrdef: text narrative of any additional information pertinent to entry including but not limited to detailed rock descriptions, location descriptions, velocity and discharge estimates, etc
text narrative of any additional information pertinent to entry including but not limited to detailed rock descriptions, location descriptions, velocity and discharge estimates, etc

Full citation of the secondary literature source used to obtain information about the slope movement or slope movement deposit

cntinfo.cntpos: Senior Geologist for Geohazards and Engineering Geology

distinfo.distliab: The North Carolina Department of Environment and Natural Resources (NCDENR), North Carolina Geological Survey (NCGS) is charged by the State of North Carolina to develop landslide hazard assessment maps for the Blue Ridge region of western North Carolina. NCGS is committed to offering its users accurate, useful, and current information. All electronic and/or hardcopy products (maps, data, and text, etc.) produced by this landslide hazard assessment program are considered public information (unless otherwise noted) and may be distributed or copied. These products, however, are intended to serve for general planning purposes only, and are provided on an "as is" basis. USE OF THESE MATERIALS CONSTITUTES ACCEPTANCE OF THIS DISCLAIMER OF LIABILITY. Therefore, the client must be aware of data conditions and bear responsibility for the appropriate use of the information with respect to possible errors, original map scale, collection methodology, currency of data, and other conditions specific to certain data. The user must be cautious when using these data, as none of the data represented here are perfect. Also, as in many complex scientific endeavors, error can be expected. In no event shall NCDENR, NCGS, or its employees be liable for any direct, indirect, incidental, special, exemplary, or consequential damages (including, but not limited to, procurement or substitute goods or services; loss of use, data, or profits; or business interruption) however caused and on any theory of liability, whether in contract, strict liability, or tort (including negligence or otherwise) arising in any way out of the use of these data, even if advised of the possibility of such damage.
